description.narrative: Effective implementation of Accelerator Lab Indonesia that contribute to the accelerated delivery of top-quality programmatic results for the SDGs

activity-description.narrative: Jakarta as it works on accelerator lab at national level

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

comment.narrative: 1.1 - 2 new sources of data per year 1.2 - 1 different type of data sources per year 1.3 - 6 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 - 2 innovation methods per Action Plan 2.1 - 1 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 - At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 - At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 - At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. 3.1 - The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 13 interaction by the end of year - 3.2 - 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 - The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 1 time per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. - The Lab team engages at least once a week across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 - Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. - Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Acclab Indonesia was only fully operational in November 2020 when all three Heads were onboard. The AccLab team was participating in dedicated 4-week AccLab Bootcamp in October 2020. The Acclab team was introduced to the CO team in Programme Staff Meeting and also conducted internal collective intelligence session with CO, both on December. The CO has identified the frontier challenge of the Lab which is on urbanization and smart city, as well as identified key government partner, which is Ministry of Research and Technology. The team also expanded its initial network through active engagement with unusual partners such as SDG Office under Regional Government in Jakarta and Design Ethnography Lab in Bandung Institute of Technology.

1.1.- 5 new data sources per year 1.2 - 6 different type of data sources per year 1.3 - 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 - 5 innovation methods per Action Plan. 2.1 - At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 - At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 - At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 - At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. 3.1 - The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network.48 interaction per year 3.2 - 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 - The Accelerator Lab Networks work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. - The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account 3.4 - Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. - Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Throughout 2021, the Accelerator Lab dedicated its efforts to strengthen the role of UNDP as a leader in Indonesia’s innovation ecosystem through broadening its network with various government stakeholders (mainly The National Planning Ministry – BAPPENAS and The National Research and Innovation Agency - BRIN), academic institutions (Design Ethnography Lab in Bandung Institute of Technology), civil society organizations (RUJAK Centre for Urban Studies and seven grassroot communities in different cities), private sector (Ecoxyztem Venture Builder) and other UN entities (UNESCO and UNDRR Office for Asia and Pacific). The team conducted lean research with BAPPENAS to influence policy design processes on flood mitigation, comprising of a public survey and ethnographic study, resulting in a community-based policy brief. In addition, the team also initiated and co-organized a capacity building initiative entitled ‘Futures Thinking in Disaster and Resilience’ with UNESCO and UNDRR which consisted of webinars, participatory workshops, and public dialogues, inviting youth and young professionals throughout Asia Pacific. Lastly, the team also conducted the Urban Innovation Challenge, together with Ecoxyztem and supported by BRIN, that crowdsourced grassroots solutions on waste management (with the support of RESTORE project), MSME digitalization and smart city – which will lead to a 6-months experimentation phase with the selected winners. In regards to programme integration, the team supported various initiative by other CO project such as DX4R for the InaRISK Hackathon Festival, DGPRU – PVE on behavioural insights, and conducted a CO-wide initiative on ‘Deep Demonstration’ with the support of Strategic Innovation Unit and BRH, among others.

1.1.- 5 new data sources per year 1.2 - 9 different type of data sources per year 1.3 - 50 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 - 10 innovation methods per Action Plan. 2.1 - At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 - At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 - At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 - At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. 3.1 - The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year 3.2 - 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 - The Accelerator Lab Networks work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. - The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account 3.4 - Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. - Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.
